title: A Bounded Measure for Estimating the Benefit of Visualization

sections.related work:
Claude Shannon’s landmark article in 1948  signifies the birth of information theory.
It has been underpinning the fields of data communication, compression, and encryption since.
As a mathematical framework, information theory provides a collection of useful measures, many of which, such as Shannon entropy , cross entropy , mutual information , and Kullback-Leibler divergence  are widely used in applications of
physics, biology, neurology, psychology, and computer science
(e.g., visualization, computer graphics, computer vision, data mining, machine learning), and so on.
In this work, we also consider Jensen-Shannon divergence  in detail. Information theory has been used extensively in visualization [ref]9.
It has enabled many applications in visualization, including
scene and shape complexity analysis by Feixas et al.  and Rigau et al. ,
light source placement by Gumhold ,
view selection in mesh rendering by Vázquez et al. 4 and Feixas et al. ,
attribute selection by Ng and Martin ,
view selection in volume rendering by Bordoloi and Shen , and Takahashi and Takeshima ,
multi-resolution volume visualization by Wang and Shen ,
focus of attention in volume rendering by Viola et al. ,
feature highlighting by Jänicke and Scheuermann 6 5,
and Wang et al. ,
transfer function design by Bruckner and Möller ,
and Ruiz et al.  ,
multi-modal data fusion by Bramon et al. ,
isosurface evaluation by Wei et al. 0,
measuring observation capacity by Bramon et al. ,
measuring information content by Biswas et al. ,
proving the correctness of “overview first, zoom, details-on-demand” by Chen and Jänicke 3 and Chen et al. [ref]9, and
confirming visual multiplexing by Chen et al. 5. Ward first suggested that information theory might be an underpinning theory for visualization 5.
Chen and Jänicke 3 outlined an information-theoretic framework for visualization, and it was further enriched by Xu et al. 2 and Wang and Shen 8 in the context of scientific visualization.
Chen and Golan proposed an information-theoretic measure for analyzing the cost-benefit of visualization processes and visual analytics workflows 1.
It was used to frame an observation study showing that human developers usually entered a huge amount of knowledge into a machine learning model 3.
It motivated an empirical study confirming that knowledge could be detected and measured quantitatively via controlled experiments 8.
It was used to analyze the cost-benefit of different virtual reality applications
0.
It formed the basis of a systematic methodology for improving the cost-benefit of visual analytics workflows .
It survived qualitative falsification by using arguments in visualization 1.
It offered a theoretical explanation of “visual abstraction” 5.
This work continues the path of theoretical developments in visualization 2, and is intended to improve the original cost-benefit formula 1, in order to make it more intuitive and usable in practical visualization applications.
